article.description: Kyle Korver scored 27 points as No. 18 Creighton matched the highest win total in school history with a 67-66 victory over Fresno State.

related.description: Kyle Korver and Creighton made the most of their national attention with a close win over Fresno State.
related.linkText: Katz: Creighton shines under the lights
related.title: Creighton showcases versatility in win over Bulldogs
related.headline: Creighton showcases versatility in win over Bulldogs

article.headline: Korver's precision from outside leads Bluejays
article.linkText: Korver sparks Creighton's comeback over Fresno State
article.story:
OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Creighton's Kyle Korver tried to downplay the shooting exhibition he put on Saturday against Fresno State.
Bulldogs gaining attention
OMAHA, Neb. -- Fresno State hadn't been on national television all season. Not once. Remember, the Jerry Tarkanian days were over last season and apparently with that went the Bulldogs' exposures.

That's why their Bracket Buster Saturday game against Creighton was must-see-TV for the Bulldogs. And, Fresno State coach Ray Lopes is hoping the selection committee saw that it should end up being worthy of a bid if it can't win the WAC tournament.

"I hope the country saw a good basketball team that played hard, tough and competed,'' Lopes said. "This event was a win-win for us. It was a tough game against a ranked team undefeated at home in a great atmosphere. We were this close (one point) to getting a win.''

But the Bulldogs don't have much margin for error. Fresno State (19-6) had the most to gain of any of the 18 Bracket Buster Saturday teams because the Bulldogs were playing the only ranked team in the field. Fresno State could have strengthened its case for a potential at-large berth with a road win in late February. That was the purpose of this event. We'll see if it makes a difference that it came close.

"But we've got to beat Nevada at home Saturday, get to 13-3 in the league and get one of two on the road (at Tulsa and at Rice) to close the season,'' Lopes said. "If we can win the conference championship then we should go. To me winning a conference championship over 18 games should carry a lot of weight.''

Normally in the WAC it would. But while the league is as competitive as it has been in years from spots one to six, the parity is hurting the overall perception of the league. Hawaii, Tulsa, Louisiana Tech, Rice and Nevada could all win the conference tournament. That's good news for a competitive field in Tulsa but not so for Fresno State if it's chances for a berth remain tenuous.

While Bracket Buster Saturday gave Lopes and the Bulldogs exposure they desperately needed, Lopes has been doing a masterful job with this team amid two NCAA investigations from the Tarkanian era. Lopes said he thought the Bulldogs would win 14 or 15 games. Instead, Lopes was second to Tom Herrion of the College of Charleston with the best record of any first-year coach this season (prior to Saturday).

Lopes mirrored this team after his mentor and former boss Kelvin Sampson at Oklahoma. The Bulldogs are focused first on defense and rebounding before offense. The players bought into working hard, as Lopes won't stand for anyone drifting.

Three starters were benched -- Hiram Fuller, Rolando Todd and Damon Jackson -- for the first few minutes for a minor curfew violation Friday night. They were loitering in the lobby, claiming they were trying to get a few of the free Doubletree cookies that helped make that hotel chain famous. But Lopes wouldn't put up with any lip from the players. The Bulldogs didn't disappoint him, putting the distraction aside and nearly pulling off the upset. They've got more work to do to get the attention of the committee but Saturday was a start.

And it was well worth the trip.

-- ESPN.com's Andy Katz
He launched a school-record 15 3-point attempts, and the way he figures, some were bound to go in. Seven did, and they were the difference as the Bluejays (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) escaped with a 67-66 victory in one of Saturday's Bracket Buster matchups. "I was pretty aggressive, and some went down,'' Korver said. "Don't give me too much credit. I put up 15 of them.'' Korver finished with 27 points and broke the school's season record for 3-pointers. He has 105 in a season during which he has been the main focus of opposing defenses. "He came to play,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "His teammates fed off him. It's been a tremendous burden for Kyle to carry all year, and at times he has not done a good job with it. Today he came ready to play. It was a big part of us being able to win the game.'' It was the only reason, Fresno State coach Ray Lopes said. The Bulldogs shot better than the Bluejays, they outrebounded them, and they blocked five shots. "We couldn't contain Korver,'' Lopes said. "He really hurt us. We did everything we could defensively. We executed our game plan as best we could on him. Great players just do that.'' Korver's 3-pointer with 11:43 left gave the Bluejays (24-3) the lead for good, but the win wasn't secure until Fresno State's Damon Jackson shot an air ball on a 3-point attempt that would have tied the score. Renaldo Major put in the rebound at the buzzer, leaving Fresno State (19-6) a point short in the made-for-television matchup between the first-place teams in the Western Athletic Conference and the Missouri Valley. "It was very good to see our team on a day we didn't shoot the ball well, and when we got down in the second half to pick up our defense and our rebounding and find another way to win a game,'' Altman said. The Bluejays shot only 40.4 percent from the field, 35.7 percent in the second half. Creighton missed nine of its first 10 shots in the second half. Noel Felix put Fresno State up 47-39 before Creighton went on its decisive run, holding the Bulldogs without a field goal for nearly nine minutes while outscoring them 20-4. "We were really soft to start the second half,'' Altman said. "My speech at half must have put them to sleep because we weren't very good. A lot it was missed shots. We didn't come close to guarding them. Then in a couple minutes we started to pick it up.'' The Bluejays rallied as they fed off the emotion of the Civic Auditorium sellout crowd of 9,329. "If anything, they played with more of a sense of urgency,'' Lopes said. "We had that lull where we couldn't stop them, and we couldn't make any baskets.'' Mike Grimes added 11 points and Brody Deren had 10 for the Bluejays. Terry Pettis scored 17 points to lead Fresno State, while Felix added 16 and Major and Jonathan Woods each had 12. Woods had 11 rebounds. Three of Fresno's regular starters -- Rolando Todd, Hiram Fuller and Jackson -- were held out of the opening lineup. Lopes said the three committed a minor team violation Friday night. Jackson, who averages 13.3 points, had only two in 23 minutes. Fuller, averaging 10.4, was limited to two in 17 minutes. "Those guys have to learn that one mistake like that can throw off the team's chemistry,'' Lopes said. Korver had two 3-pointers and 10 points during the Bluejays' decisive spurt, which saw Creighton go ahead 59-51. Two free throws by Major closed Creighton's lead to 67-64 with 1:49 left. After Tyler McKinney missed a 3-pointer for the Bluejays, Fresno had a chance to tie but Woods was off-target from in close, and Korver came up with the rebound. McKinney turned the ball over seconds later when he tried to force a pass inside to Korver with 18 seconds left. Jackson missed a 3, but Fresno State maintained possession with 5.2 seconds later after the ball went out of bounds off Creighton. "Every time we made a little run, they answered,'' Deren said. "They've got some really athletic guys that make some plays some of the guys in our league can't do.''
